facts.text: This is Civil Appeal No. 1527 of 1968 under s. 123 of the Jammu and Kashmir Representation of the People Act, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal to. 1527 of 1968. Appeal under s. 123 of the Jammu and Kashmir Representation of the People Act, 1957 from the Judgment and order dated April 29, 1968 of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court in Election, Petition No. 33 of 1967.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 29, 1968 of Jammu and Kashmir High Court in Election Petition No. 33 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal under s. 123 of the Jammu and Kashmir Representation of the People Act, 1957 from the Judgment and order dated April 29, 1968 of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court in Election, Petition No. 33 of 1967. N. Bhalgotra and S. S. Khanduja, for the appellant.

facts.text: High Court dismissed election petition for setting aside election of respondent Jagat Ram Aryan to legislative assembly from Bhaderwah scheduled caste assembly constituency.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is directed against a judgment of a Single Judge of the High Court of Jammu and Kashmir dismissing an election petition for setting aside the election of the respondent Jagat Ram Aryan to the legislative assembly of the State of Jammu Kashmir from the Bhaderwah scheduled cast assembly companystituency.

facts.text: Last date for filing nomination papers was January 20, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The last date for filing the numberination papers was January 20, 1967. The date of scrutiny of numberination papers was January 23, 1967. The date of poll was February 21, 1967. The date of companynting and declaration of result was March 1, 1967.

facts.text: Date of scrutiny of nomination papers was January 23, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The last date for filing the numberination papers was January 20, 1967. The date of scrutiny of numberination papers was January 23, 1967. The date of poll was February 21, 1967.

facts.text: Date of poll was February 21, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The date of scrutiny of numberination papers was January 23, 1967. The date of poll was February 21, 1967. The date of companynting and declaration of result was March 1, 1967.

facts.text: Date of counting and declaration of result was March 1, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: The date of poll was February 21, 1967. The date of companynting and declaration of result was March 1, 1967. Several candidates filed their numberination papers from this companystituency.

facts.text: Candidates: 1. Jagat Ram Aryan, 2. Faquir Chand, 3. Narain Dass, 4. Nikka Ram, 5. Bhagat Ram, 6. Om Parkash, 7. Swami Raj.

anchor.surface_text: Several candidates filed their numberination papers from this companystituency. The candidates were  1  Jagat Ram Aryan, Faquir Chand,  3  Narain Dass,  4  Nikka Ram,  5  Bhagat Ram,  6  Om Parkash and  7  Swami Raj.

facts.text: First five candidates filed nomination papers on January 23, 1967 before Assistant Returning Officer Kahan Singh, Tehsildar of Bhaderwah.

anchor.surface_text: The first five filed their numberination papers on January 23, 1967 before the Assistant Returning Officer, Kahan Singh, a Tehsildar of Bhaderwah. On scrutiny of the numberination pipers, the Returning Officer Abdul Gani accepted as valid the numberination papers of Jagat Ram and Faquir Chand

facts.text: Returning Officer Abdul Gani accepted nomination papers of Jagat Ram and Faquir Chand, rejected others.

anchor.surface_text: On scrutiny of the numberination pipers, the Returning Officer Abdul Gani accepted as valid the numberination papers of Jagat Ram and Faquir Chand and rejected the numberinations papers of the remaining candidates for various reasons.

facts.text: At poll, contest between Jagat Ram (Congress candidate) and Faquir Chand (National Conference candidate); Jagat Ram secured more votes and declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: At the poll the companytest was between Jagat Ram, the companygress candidate and Faquir Chand, the National Conference candidate. Respondent Jagat Ram having secured larger number of votes was declared elected.

facts.text: Appellant, a voter in the constituency, filed election petition to set aside respondent's election on ground of improper rejection of nominations of Narain Dass, Nikka Ram, Bhagat Ram.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, a voter in the companystituency, filed the election petition for setting aside the respondents election on the ground that the numberination papers of Narain Dass, Nikka Ram and Bhagat Ram were improperly rejected.

facts.text: High Court found nomination paper of Bhagat Ram properly rejected; finding not challenged.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found. that the numberination paper of Bhagat Ram was properly rejected and this finding is numberlonger challenged.

facts.text: Nikka Ram's nomination rejected on grounds: 1. did not make/subscribe oath per s.51(a) J&K Const., 2. not scheduled caste member, 3. father's name incorrectly shown in electoral rolls.

anchor.surface_text: The numberination paper of Nikka Ram was rejected on three grounds  1  he did number make and subscribe the oath or affirmation as required by s. 51  a  of the Jammu Kashmir Constitution  2  he was number a member of a scheduled caste and  3  his fathers name was number companyrectly shown in the electoral rolls.

facts.text: Narain Dass's nomination rejected on grounds: 1. did not make/subscribe oath per s.51(a), 2. not scheduled caste member.

anchor.surface_text: The numberination paper of Narain Dass was rejected on two grounds  1  he did number make and subscribe the oath or affirmation as required by s. 51  a  and  2  he was number a member of a scheduled caste.

facts.text: High Court found Narain Dass and Nikka Ram are members of scheduled caste Megh.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that both Narain Dass and Nikka Ram were members of the scheduled caste Megh.

facts.text: High Court held error in Nikka Ram's father's name in electoral roll not ground for rejection per s.44(4) JK ROP Act 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It also held that the error in the electoral roll with regard to the name of Nikka Rams father was number a ground for rejecting his numberination paper having regard to s. 44  4  of the J. K. Representation of the People Act, 1957.

facts.text: High Court rejected contention that Narain Dass did not make deposit of Rs.125 per s.45(2).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also rejected the addi- tional companytention that Narain Dass had number made a deposit of Rs. 125 in companyformity with s. 45  2  of the Act.

facts.text: Only issue: whether Narain Dass and Nikka Ram made and subscribed oath/affirmation per s.51(a) JK Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: All these findings are numberlonger challenged. The only point number in issue is whether Narain Dass and Nikka Ram made and subscribed the oath or affirmation as required by s. 51  a  of the J. K. Constitution.

facts.text: Returning Officer and Assistant Returning Officer authorised by Election Commission via notification No.3/4 JK/65 for oath.

anchor.surface_text: The Returning Officer and the Assistant Returning Officer were authorised in this behalf by the Election Commission of India by numberification No. 3/4 J K/65 as the persons before whom the oath or affirmation companyld be made and subscribed.

facts.text: Common case: Narain Dass and Nikka Ram filed signed oath forms with nomination papers.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon case that along with their numberination papers. both Narain Dass and Nikka Ram filed oath forms signed by them.

facts.text: Petitioner's case: Narain Dass and Nikka Ram made oaths and signed forms in presence of Assistant Returning Officer at presentation.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case is that at the time of the presentation of their numberination papers both Narain Dass and Nikka Ram made, oaths and signed the oath forms in the presence of the Assistant Returning Officer.

facts.text: Petitioner examined witnesses: Narain Dass, Nikka Ram, Abdul Qayum, Abdul Rehman.

anchor.surface_text: In support of this case, the appellant examined Narain Dass, Nikka Ram, Abdul Qayum and Abdul Rehman.

facts.text: Respondent's case: Narain Dass and Nikka Ram did not make/subscribe oath before Asst RO; forms pre-filled and signed.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case is that Narain Dass and Nikka Ram did number make or subscribe any oath or affirmation before the Assistant Returning Officer, that the oath forms had been filled up and signed before they were presented to him and were number signed in his. presence.

facts.text: Respondent examined: Kahan Singh (Asst RO), Abdul Gani (RO).

anchor.surface_text: In support of his case the respondent examined Kahan Singh, the Assistant Returning Officer and Abdul Gani, the Returning Officer.

facts.text: High Court accepted respondent's case on oath.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court accepted the respondents case.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Narain Dass and Nikka Ram did not make/subscribe oath before Asst RO; did not sign forms in his presence.

anchor.surface_text: In agreement with the High Court we hold that neither Narain Dass and Nikka Ram, signed the oath forms before the Assistant Returning Officer number did they make the oath or affirmation before him.

facts.text: Oath forms filed by Narain Dass and Nikka Ram did not bear endorsement of Asst RO; no certificate furnished.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted by the appellant that the oath forms filed by Narain Dass and Nikka Ram did number bear any endorsement of the Assistant Returning Officer, stating that the oath or affirmation had been made and subscribed before him number was any certificate of such endorsement furnished to them.

facts.text: Narain Dass and Nikka Ram could not produce evidence of oath to RO Abdul Gani; opportunity given for affidavits but none filed.

anchor.surface_text: Neither Narain Dass number Nikka Ram companyld produce before the Returning Officer Abdul Gani any evidence of their making and subscribing the oath or affirmation. Abdul Gani gave them an opportunity to produce affidavits in proof, of this,, fact but they did number file any affidavit or any other evidence before him.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeal is dismissed. There will be numberorder as to companyts.
Appeal under s. 123 of the Jammu and Kashmir Representation of the People Act, 1957 from the Judgment and order dated April 29, 1968

arguments.claim: Narain Dass and Nikka Ram made oaths and signed the oath forms in the presence of the Assistant Returning Officer at the time of presentation of nomination papers

anchor.surface_text: The appellants case is that at the time of the presentation of their numberination papers both Narain Dass and Nikka Ram made, oaths and signed the oath forms in the presence of the Assistant Returning Officer.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: in Dass and Nikka Ram filed with the Assistant Returning Officer signed and filled up oath forms along with their numberination papers. In our opinion

arguments.court_reasoning: Witnesses interested; testimony rejected in favour of Asst RO; no endorsement; no affidavits produced to RO

arguments.claim: Narain Dass and Nikka Ram did not make or subscribe oath or affirmation before the Assistant Returning Officer; oath forms filled up and signed before presentation and not in his presence

anchor.surface_text: The respondents case is that Narain Dass and Nikka Ram did number make or subscribe any oath or affirmation before the Assistant Returning Officer, that the oath forms had been filled up and signed before they were presented to him and were number signed in his. presence.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ribed the oath before the Assistant Returning Officer when in fact they did number make or subscribe

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court accepted; Supreme Court agrees after evaluating evidence

arguments.claim: Petitioner's witnesses are interested and their testimony cannot be preferred over that of the Assistant Returning Officer

anchor.surface_text: Narain Dass and Nikka Ram were Jana Sangh candidates. Abdul Qayum and Abdul Rehman were their party men. All of them were interested witnesses. Having regard to all the materials on the record it is impossible to prefer their testimony to that of Kahan Singh.

arguments.claim: Absence of endorsement by Assistant Returning Officer on oath forms suggests no oath was made and subscribed before him

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted by the appellant that the oath forms filed by Narain Dass and Nikka Ram did number bear any endorsement of the Assistant Returning Officer, stating that the oath or affirmation had been made and subscribed before him number was any certificate of such endorsement furnished to them. The absence of the endorsement on the oath forms tend to suggest that numberoath or affirmation was made and subscribed by them before the Assistant Returning Officer.

arguments.claim: Narain Dass and Nikka Ram produced no evidence of oath subscription to Returning Officer despite opportunity to file affidavits

anchor.surface_text: Neither Narain Dass number Nikka Ram could produce before the Returning Officer Abdul Gani any evidence of their making and subscribing the oath or affirmation. Abdul Gani gave them an opportunity to produce affidavits in proof, of this,, fact but they did number file any affidavit or any other evidence before him.

arguments.claim: Filing signed and filled oath forms with nomination papers does not constitute compliance with s.51(a) requirement to make and subscribe oath before authorised person

anchor.surface_text: On January 23, 1967 both Narain Dass and Nikka Ram filed with the Assistant Returning Officer signed and filled up oath forms along with their numberination papers. In our opinion this, was number sufficient companypliance with the requirement of s. 5 1  a .

Constitution did number exist on the date of scrutiny of numberinations.

arguments.claim: Breach of Election Commission Handbook Instruction No.7(7) by Asst RO does not validate candidates' non-compliance with oath requirement

anchor.surface_text: Kahan Singh the Assistant Returning Officer was number companyversant with these instructions. He did number ask either Narain Dass or Nikka Ram to read the oath or to sign the oath form in his presence. But the breach of these instructions does number entitle them to say that they had made and subscribed the oath before the Assistant Returning Officer when in fact they did number make or subscribe the oath before him.

arguments.claim: Nomination paper of Bhagat Ram was properly rejected

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found. that the numberination paper of Bhagat Ram was properly rejected and this finding is numberlonger challenged.

arguments.claim: Candidates likely unaware of oath requirement under recently amended s.51(a) and thus omitted to comply

anchor.surface_text: It should be remembered that the requirement of, making and subscribing an oath or affirmation was inserted in s. 51  a  of the J. K. Constitution by the Constitution Sixth Amendment Act, 1965. There is ground for believing that Narain Dass and Nikka Ram were number aware of this provision and for this reason they omitted to make or subscribe any oath or affirmation before the Assistant Returning Officer.

holdings.text: Neither Narain Dass nor Nikka Ram signed the oath forms before the Assistant Returning Officer nor did they make the oath or affirmation before him.

anchor.surface_text: In agreement with the High Court we hold that neither Narain Dass and Nikka Ram, signed the oath forms before the Assistant Returning Officer number did they make the oath or affirmation before him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Witness testimony evaluation preferring disinterested Asst RO over interested petitioner witnesses; absence of endorsement on forms; no affidavits or evidence produced to RO despite opportunity.

holdings.text: Filing signed and filled up oath forms along with nomination papers was not sufficient compliance with the requirement of s.51(a) J&K Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: On January 23, 1967 both Narain Dass and Nikka Ram filed with the Assistant Returning Officer signed and filled up oath forms along with their numberination papers. In our opinion this, was number sufficient companypliance with the requirement of s. 5 1  a .

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.51(a) requires actual making and subscribing before authorised officer; mere pre-signed forms inadequate.

holdings.text: On the date of scrutiny, Narain Dass and Nikka Ram were not qualified under s.51(a) J&K Constitution; nomination papers liable to rejection under s.47(2)(a) JK ROP Act 1957.

anchor.surface_text: In Pashupati Nath v. Harihar Prasad 1 this Court held that-the numberination paper was liable to be rejected under s. 3 6 2 a of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 companyresponding to s. 47 2 a of the J. K. Representation of the People Act,, 1957 if the qualification required by Art. 173 a of the Constitution companyresponding to s. 51 a of the J. K. Constitution did number exist on the date of scrutiny of numberinations.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Qualification must exist on scrutiny date per s.47(2)(a); applies Pashupati Nath precedent; no oath compliance means no qualification.

holdings.text: Error in electoral roll regarding Nikka Ram's father's name not a ground for rejecting nomination under s.44(4) JK ROP Act 1957.

anchor.surface_text: It also held that the error in the electoral roll with regard to the name of Nikka Rams father was number a ground for rejecting his numberination paper having regard to s. 44 4 of the J. K. Representation of the People Act, 1957.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit statutory provision s.44(4) precludes such error as rejection ground; High Court finding affirmed and unchallenged.

holdings.text: Narain Dass made the required deposit of Rs.125 under s.45(2) JK ROP Act 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court also rejected the addi- tional companytention that Narain Dass had number made a deposit of Rs. 125 in companyformity with s. 45 2 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Respondent contention rejected by High Court; finding affirmed and unchallenged.

holdings.text: Breach of Election Commission instructions by Asst RO does not validate candidate's failure to make and subscribe oath.

anchor.surface_text: Kahan Singh the Assistant Returning Officer was number companyversant with these instructions. He did number ask either Narain Dass or Nikka Ram to read the oath or to sign the oath form in his presence. But the breach of these instructions does number entitle them to say that they had made and subscribed the oath before the Assistant Returning Officer when in fact they did number make or subscribe the oath before him.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Candidate must comply independently; officer's procedural lapse no excuse for substantive non-compliance.

holdings.text: Narain Dass and Nikka Ram were members of scheduled caste Megh.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court found that both Narain Dass and Nikka Ram were members of the scheduled caste Megh.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court factual finding affirmed and unchallenged.
